X.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. operations. Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. is currently implementing their Process Safety Management Program. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc.  

XI.	Management Program
Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Chuck Brown, General Manager, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.

III.	Facility Identification
The Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. facility is located at 8751 West 50th Street in McCook, Illinois.  The facility is a producer of specialty meatballs, Italian beef, pizza toppings, and specialty breakfast meats for the foodservice industry nationwide. 

The NAICS code for the facility is 311612.  Many areas of the plant are refrigerated to preserve ingredients and products.   

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one (1) refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating ingredients, process areas, and products. 

The amount of ammonia in the refrigeration system is approximately 38,000 pounds.  The refrigeration system is used to cool process rooms, holding freezers, coolers, docks and blast freezers.  This refrigeration system uses ammonia refrigerant in a three (3) stage evaporation/condensation cycle.  The "low pressure" equipment contains (3) Freezer Evaporators, (2) Blast Cells, (4) Spiral Freezers, (1) Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR), (1) Oil Pot and (3) Booster Compressors.  The "intermediate pressure" equipment contains (1) Corridor Evaporator, (10) Process Room Evaporators, (3) Dock Evaporators, (5) Roof Top Units, (1) Water Chiller, (1) Gravy Chiller, (1) High Temp Pump Package (HTPR), (1) Oil Pot, (1) Swing Compressor, and (3) High Stage Compressors.  The "high-pressure" equipment includes the (3) Evaporative Condensers and (1) High Pressure Receiver (HPR) and associated piping/valves.

VI.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The first audit of the PSM program occurred on January 21, 2011, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
¿	Employee Participation - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
¿	Process Safety Information - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of February 28, 2013.
¿	Process Hazard Analysi

s - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. conducted a thorough PHA revalidation study for the refrigeration system on February 26-28, 2013.
¿	Operating Procedures - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. developed initial operating procedures for the refrigeration system during February and March 2008.  Annually, the operating procedures are reviewed and certified as accurate.
¿	Training - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.
 
¿	Management of Change - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 
¿	Pre-Startup Review - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
¿	Mechanical Integrity - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are develope

d and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. formalized maintenance procedures for the refrigeration system during February and March 2008.
¿	Contractor Qualifications - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.
¿	Incident Investigation - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 
¿	Compliance Audit - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  An initial compliance audit was conducted on January 21, 2011.  
¿	Hot Work Permits - Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has updated a best management practice for hot work.  Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. updated their hot work permit procedures for the refrigeration system during May 2006.
 

VII.	Five-Year Accident History
The Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. facility has not experienced an accidental anhyd

rous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

VIII.	Emergency Response Program
Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 

Upon facility start-up, Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and interacted (i.e. onsite inspections) with the McCook Fire Department. 

Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc. has coordinated their ERP with the McCook Fire Department.  This coordination effort included providing the agency with a copy of our ERP, and providing a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with McCook Fire Department personnel to discuss the facilities operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with McCook Fire Department personnel.

Capitol Wholesale Meats Inc.'s hazardous materials response team is responsible for investigating and assisting the McCook Fire Department (if necessary) with response to accidental releases of ammonia. 

Several employees on staff have received HAZWOPER training through classroom instruction, on-the-job training and drills. The current HAZWOPER training includes the incident commander, first responder awareness level, the first responder operations level, and hazardous materials technician training.   

The facility has four (4) windsocks onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.

The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E.
